item.description:
What are we doing?

We are looking for a small group of fast hikers to hike the entire Davis Path from Rte 302 up to the summit of Washington, stopping at Mt. Isolation along the way. This isn't really a peak-bagging trip - if you need these peaks, there are much easier (and much shorter) ways to get them! This hike is geared towards people who enjoy long, fast day hikes and are looking for a physical challenge.  Campground space nearby is available for the night before.

 

Trip Summary

On this  fast-paced one-way trip we will  hike almost 20 miles and  climb about 7,500 feet. Book time is over 15 hours - but our plan/goal is to hike faster than book time and finish in under 12 hours. This trip is considered to be   ADVANCED/EXTREME  because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain. You should be able to hike 2+ mph - even when climbing. Between the hiking and the car spots, this will be a LONG day - and you should be prepared to hike out in the dark if we run behind schedule. You may want to stay over/camp the night before and/or the night after.

We will meet at 5:00 am at the Ammonusuc Ravine Trailhead hiker parking lot a half mile below the Mt. Washington Cog Railway station, spot some cars, and then drive to the Davis Path trailhead on Rte. 302.  We'll take Davis Path all the way up to Washington (15 miles - so you must be able to climb strong all day!), stopping at Isolation along the way, and possibly exploring the spur trails to Crawford, Stairs, or Resolution (52-with-a-view peaks) time permitting.  Coming down from Washington, we'll take either the Ammonusuc Ravine Trail (if we've made good enough time to descend in daylight) or the Jewell trail. If everyone in the group wants to and there is time remaining, we will have the option, instead of ending at Washington, to heading down via one or more of the southern Presidential summits.

While we have researched this trip, we expect all participants to bring a map, and be familiar with the route.  We start as a group, stay as a group, and finish as a group. 

Weather

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel - in this event, we will let you know by noon time on Sunday the 9th at the latest.  Mountain weather is subject to rapid changes and extreme conditions. We will assess trail and weather conditions during the hike and will adjust the trip plan as necessary.

Clothing and Equipment

Below is a list describing the minimum required clothing and equipment to participate in this event.

Footwear: Sturdy hiking boots/trail runners.

Clothing: Dress in layers to easily regulate body temperature. Wear synthetic shirt/pants and bring a fleece jacket/wool sweater. ABSOLUTELY NO COTTON. It could be very chilly atop Mt. Washington - bring hat and gloves as well.

Outerwear: Waterproof/windproof rain shell with hood, and waterproof/windproof pants.

Food and Water: High-energy snacks, food for lunch, enough water to stay properly hydrated during the trip (3 Liters recommended) (We can refill water at the Washington summit).

Other Essential Gear: Map and compass. Plastic whistle. Headlamp with two sets of spare batteries. Personal first aid kit. An emergency space blanket (e.g. mylar). Small pocket knife or multi-purpose tool. Toilet kit (e.g. hand sanitizer, toilet paper and a zip-lock bag to pack out your used personal hygiene items). Sunscreen. Bug Spray. Lip balm. Sunglasses. Waterproof cover for your pack.

Optional Items: Trekking poles. Camera.

Signing Up

To sign up for this hike, you should be an experienced hiker who has recently completed trips of similar distance and elevation - faster than book time. Please answer all RSVP questions - if we haven't hiked with you before, we may also be contacted you to gain further insight into your capabilities and interests.  If we determine that this trip is not a good fit for you, we will remove you from the list.  Similarly, if you are on the list and your plans change, please be sure to take yourself off the list asap in order to give a fair shot to others who may want to come.

Directions

We will meet at 5:00 am at the Ammonusuc Ravine Trailhead hiker parking lot a half mile below the Mt. Washington Cog Railway station to spot cars, geared up and ready to go.  If you do not wish to drive up with all your gear at the ready, then plan to arrive early at the trailhead to gear up.  Because of the time we need to complete this large trip, we cannot wait for latecomers.  This parking lot is approximately 3 hours from Boston, not counting food/gas/coffee/rest stops. 

Night Before  

Because of the early start time, you may want to arrive on Sunday. We have reserved a campsite nearby, with some space for additional participants.  There are also indoor accomodatios at the AMC Highland Center, in Bretton Woods, and in Twin Mountain.  Let us know your plans.

=====

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you and your guests acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code described at www.hikesafe.com; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, financial loss, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
item.name: Mount Washington via a Full traverse of the Davis Path
